query: Which companies are most exposed to drought risk?

nodes.label: drought
nodes.description: A drought is an extended period of unusually dry weather marked by a significant and sustained lack of precipitation, falling below a specific threshold over a large area for more than a month

nodes.label: agriculture sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve the cultivation of crops and raising of livestock for food, fibre, and other products essential for human life and industry.

nodes.label: slow onset events
nodes.description: Slow onset events evolve gradually from incremental changes over many years or from increased frequency or intensity of recurring events. As defined in the Cancun Adaptation Framework (2010), slow onset events include risks and impacts from rising temperatures, desertification, biodiversity loss, land and forest degradation, glacial retreat, ocean acidification, sea level rise, and salinization.

nodes.label: Drought forecasting systems
nodes.description: Drought forecasting systems use models fed by climatic and atmospheric data (historical/seasonal weather patterns, real-time meteorological monitoring, and weather forecasts) to predict the probability of a drought occurring in a region or area of interest in the future (up to approximately three months). Drought forecasting systems are an important part of early warning systems, as they provide lead-time to planners for threat responses, which helps minimize drought impact risk.

nodes.label: Adaptation technologies
nodes.description: Adaptation technologies are systems, tools, processes and innovations that facilitate the process of adjusting to and managing the current and future effects of climate change.

nodes.label: construction sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve planning, designing and building infrastructure, residential, and commercial structures.

nodes.label: sand encroachment
nodes.description: Sand encroachment occurs generally in arid to semi-arid regions when grains of sand are carried by winds and form sandy accumulation on coasts, along watercourses and on cultivated or uncultivated land causing major material and socioeconomic damage.

nodes.label: plastic leaching
nodes.description: The process of when plastic elements contaminate its surrounding environment.

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 2
nodes.description: SDG2: zero hunger

nodes.label: coastal erosion
nodes.description: The erosion of the coast due to slow and sudden onset climate impacts

nodes.label: fishing sector
nodes.description: Activities involving the catching, processing, and selling of fish for food, recreation, and industry.

nodes.label: risk
nodes.description: Risk is the potential for adverse consequences resulting from the dynamic interplay between (climate-related) hazards, exposure, and vulnerability of affected human or ecological systems.

nodes.label: increasing temperatures
nodes.description: Earth's temperature has risen since 1850 due to human induced climate change. Increasing temperatures intensify the hydrologic cycle, causing dry regions to become drier and wet regions to become wetter.

nodes.label: forestry sector
nodes.description: Activities that relate to the production of goods and services from forests.

nodes.label: mixed farming
nodes.description: Mixed farming combines crop and animal production on the same farm.

nodes.label: trade sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the wholesale and retail selling of goods.

nodes.label: terrestrial risk
nodes.description: Terrestrial means "of the earth" and relates to the ecological system that includes all living organisms and their interactions within land-based environments, such as forests, grasslands, and deserts.

nodes.label: healthcare sector
nodes.description: This sector provides medical services, manufactures medical equipment, and develops pharmaceuticals to maintain and improve health.

nodes.label: glacial lake outburst flood
nodes.description: A Glacial Lake Outburst Flood (GLOF) is the sudden release of water from a glacier-fed lake, caused by the melting or collapse of surrounding ice or land barriers.

nodes.label: storms
nodes.description: Storms are intense weather events with strong winds that can cause significant damage to infrastructure and ecosystems.

nodes.label: crop production
nodes.description: This area encompasses the cultivation of plants for food, feed, fibree, fuel, and other purposes. It involves activities like planting, growing, and harvesting a wide variety of crops.

nodes.label: ammonia
nodes.description: An inorganic compound of nitrogen and hydrogen produced industrially as a fertilizer and for many other uses

nodes.label: land degradation
nodes.description: A negative trend in the condition of land, expressed as long-term reduction or loss of at least one of the following: biological productivity, ecological integrity or value to humans.

nodes.label: biodiversity loss
nodes.description: Increasing air and water temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are affecting the structure, composition and functions of ecosystems. Resulting in loss of biodiversity that help support human well-being.

nodes.label: agricultural insurance
nodes.description: Insurance has become even more important as extreme weather events and climate change have increased the risks and uncertainties of farmers and agriculture-based enterprises, creating the need for agricultural insurance to protect from losses.

nodes.label: sustainable agriculture
nodes.description: Farming that meets the needs of existing and future generations, while also ensuring profitability, environmental health and social and economic equity.

nodes.label: nitrous oxide
nodes.description: Nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas 300 times more potent than carbon dioxide (CO2) that remains in the atmosphere for more than 100 years.

nodes.label: SDG target 2.b
nodes.description: Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect

nodes.label: desertification
nodes.description: Land degradation in arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas (drylands) resulting from various factors, including climatic variations and human activities.

nodes.label: glacial retreat
nodes.description: Glacial retreat is what happens when a glacier melts faster than new ice can build it back up. Directly related to increasing temperatures, it produces erosion, mudslides, flooding.

nodes.label: REDD+
nodes.description: Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in developing countries, the ‘+’ includes additional forest-related activities that protect the climate, e.g. sustainable management of forests, or forest carbon stocks

nodes.label: temperature extremes
nodes.description: Increases in the intensity, frequency, and duration of warm extremes and the decrease in those of cold extremes.

nodes.label: global warming potential
nodes.description: Global Warming Potential (GWP) is an index that compares the radiative forcing of different gases. It measures the impact of one kilogram of a greenhouse gas relative to one kilogram of CO2 over 100 years.

nodes.label: hospitality sector
nodes.description: Activities that provide lodging, food, and entertainment services to guests, including hotels, restaurants, and resorts.

nodes.label: Control of sand encroachment
nodes.description: The fundamental principle of dune fixation is that of preventing sand from moving during a long enough period to allow natural or planted vegetation to become established. If sand encroachment is to be controlled, saltation must be reduced, either by stabilizing the soil or by reducing the wind speed gradient close to the surface of the ground.

nodes.label: flood
nodes.description: Floods are the inundation of normally dry land, resulting from a mix of hydrology, climate, and human factors, varying by type and region.

nodes.label: sandstorm
nodes.description: A sandstorm is an ensemble of particles of dust or sand energetically lifted to great heights by a strong and turbulent wind

nodes.label: pesticide
nodes.description: Pesticide means any substance, or mixture of substances of chemical or biological ingredients intended for repelling, destroying or controlling any pest, or regulating plant growth. Pesticides are inherently toxic.

nodes.label: finance and insurance sector
nodes.description: Activities of businesses and institutions that provide financial services and products to individuals and organisations.

nodes.label: economic sector
nodes.description: Area of the economy in which actors engage in identical or related activities.

nodes.label: anthropogenic climate change
nodes.description: that human activity (e.g. burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natural gas) is the dominant driver of the current changes to the climate and the environment

nodes.label: precipitation extremes
nodes.description: Precipitation refers to any form of weather where substances fall from the sky, including rain, snow, sleet, or hail. Additionally, in chemistry, precipitation describes the process where a solid forms and settles out of a solution.

nodes.label: Drought-resistant crops
nodes.description: Drought-resistant crops are varieties of plants that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand prolonged periods of low water availability.

nodes.label: REDD
nodes.description: Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in developing countries

nodes.label: deforestation
nodes.description: Removal of forest and conversion of the land to non-forest use, and is the direct human-induced conversion of forested land to non-forested land

nodes.label: rural poor
nodes.description: people living outside of urban areas with limited assets or access to services

nodes.label: desert community
nodes.description: Communities that live in the desert

nodes.label: sea overwash
nodes.description: Overwash is the flow of water and sediment over a coastal dune or beach crest during storm events. This process can cause significant coastal changes in the landscape of beaches and dunes.

nodes.label: soil erosion
nodes.description: Soil erosion is defined as the accelerated removal of topsoil from the land surface through water, wind and tillage

nodes.label: exposed community
nodes.description: Communities that are significantly exposed to climate impacts due to their physical location

nodes.label: animal production
nodes.description: Animal production involves raising livestock for meat, milk, eggs, wool, hides, and other animal products.

nodes.label: salinization
nodes.description: Increasing evaporation from rising temperatures leads to the salinization of soil and water. Salts accumulate in the soils of arid environments.

nodes.label: ocean warming
nodes.description: The ocean absorbs excess heat from greenhouse gas emissions, causing rising temperatures that lead to coral bleaching and the loss of breeding grounds for marine species.

nodes.label: extreme weather
nodes.description: Extreme weather refers to events where a weather variable exceeds (or falls below) a threshold. Meaning it is significantly different from the average or usual weather pattern.

nodes.label: agricultural water management
nodes.description: planning and operation of water systems to supply water for agricultural purposes, including irrigation and livestock needs

nodes.label: Drought risk mapping
nodes.description: Drought risk mapping helps identify the areas most at risk of droughts, allowing communities to plan, as well as prepare for and mitigate possible impacts. Drought risk is calculated as the probability of negative impact caused by interactions between hazard (probability of future drought events occurring based on past, current and projected drought conditions), exposure (scale of assets and population in the area) and vulnerability (probability of assets and population being affected by droughts in the area).

nodes.label: early warning system
nodes.description: An integrated single-hazard monitoring system that warns for impending extreme weather events and climate conditions, reducing the losses and damages and saving lives.

nodes.label: water management sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the distribution, treatment, and conservation of water resources.

nodes.label: transportation sector
nodes.description: This sector involves activities to move goods and people, alongside the storage of products.

nodes.label: forest degradation
nodes.description: Land degradation in forested areas, referring to the loss of the biological wealth of a forest.

nodes.label: energy supply sector
nodes.description: The activities of industries involved in the production, distribution, and sale of energy, including electricity, gas, and renewables.

nodes.label: informal sector
nodes.description: Households employing domestic workers, for activities like cooking, cleaning and subsistence farming, for their own use.

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 15
nodes.description: SDG15: life on land

nodes.label: cryosphere risk
nodes.description: The cryosphere includes all parts of Earth's surface where water is solid, such as sea ice, glaciers, snow, ice caps, ice sheets, and frozen ground.

kg_data.query: Which companies are most exposed to drought risk?
